specs/train/approved/expose-auto-converg.message:
What happens if the image or flavor specifies auto-converge or post-copy and the compute host can't provide that functionality? Should server create fail since it could mean we aren't honoring the user request (like SLAs)? Beyond server create you could have the same issue if you, for example, create a server with these specs on a host and then cold-migrated it to another server which doesn't provide those features - would the migration fail? Would we have to copy the same checks all over the move operations (cold/live migrate, evacuate and unshelve?). This is where it gets tricky if it's something we don't validate within scheduler filters. We could potentially solve this with traits though if we exposed a capability of the virt driver and then translated the traits from the image/flavor, like this:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/645316/

Or the TPM spec:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/add-emulated-virtual-tpm.html

This can be easily solved without adding new traits... but there are some operational points :
- live-migration needs to call the scheduler filters
- all hosts supporting the autoconverge need to be in the same aggregate
- flavor needs to have a specific extra spec

Given the above, I'm okay with rather using traits because the three points aren't needed.

FWIW, the QEMU minimum version for Stein is already 2.8 [1] so you don't need to say the above 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/stein/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L224

I think at least some operators would like to still use the config options, just because this spec wouldn't accept a live-migration if the target wouldn't support the trait. Operators would rather prefer to have different performant migrations between hosts, but still have all of the hosts as targets.

IMO, these traits are not recommend to set if operators want to migrate instance between all hosts.
But operators can config these configurations if operator want *all instances* using auto-converge/postcopy.

Uh, I think it could be a Placement API issue.
If you ask for two traits, you get ResourceProviders having *both* of them. AFAIK, Placement doesn't support (yet) to say "I want this and that, but if this, I don't care about that".

FWIW, I think what you need is to only have two traits for a RP:
- a trait AUTO_CONVERGE_ONLY
- a trait AUTO_CONVERGE_AND_POST_COPY

Operators wanting post-copy would use the other trait (implicitely asking for autoconverge), while operators caring about autoconverge would use the first one.

That's why we need to translate the metadata to traits internal, if the metadata is false, then we don't translate metadata to trait(instance not care the selected destination whether support/not support these features), and disable these features during live migration(libvirt will check metadata or request spec as you say).

So if I create a server with a flavor and image that has neither of these new metadata, or the value is false, then my server can go anywhere (doesn't need to be a libvirt host) and if it's live migrated, it can be auto-converged or post-copied based on host configuration (assuming a libvirt host).

But if I create a server with a flavor or image that has either of those values as true, then the server has to land on a libvirt host (reporting the capability, linked via required trait in the GET /allocation_candidates call) and furthermore, the value in the flavor/image *overrides* the host configuration, is that correct?

I'm not sure why this alternative is worse than what is proposed. As noted above, the libvirt driver could report support capabilities for auto-converge and post-copy as traits, and then operators can configure flavors that either require or forbid the use of hosts with those capabilities, then the user picks the flavor that matches their requirement (or if they don't care it's a flavor without either). I guess the big drawback there is you could have an explosion of flavors for users that care one way or the other, and users that don't care.

Based on our discussions there is a clear use cases around:

* some applications do not want the risk of being rebooted due to a network failure during live-migration post copy, they would rather the VM is paused instead.

* some applications are very performance sensitive, so do not want their performance throttled back by the auto converge feature, and would rather take the risks involved in post copy. Note: auto converge is generally only enabled instead of post copy when an operator is not happy with the reboot risk post copy introduces, and would rather users opt into the risk if they don't want to be throttled back

* some applications would like to avoid the post copy risk and avoid having its performance throttled, i.e. they would prefer a longer pause of their VM to the alternatives.

Auto-converge will slow down CPU and memory I/O until live-migration done.
Post-copy will boot a new vm on destination compute node, and remote access the source vm's memory, migrate all memory to destination vm. The danger is that if the network between the two compute nodes is broken, then both vm will be error.
So it's configurable.

> This is my preferred solution (it was never fully implemented):
 > https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/pike/approved/live-migration-per-instance-timeout.html

The problems that spec 'live-migration-per-instance-timeout' wants to solve is: control long time live migration, auto execute force-complete/abort. The usage of auto-converge/post-copy are still controlled by compute node.

The problems this spec wants to solve is: control the usage of auto-converge/post-copy both by flavor/image properties and compute node.

So to be clear:
- We use these keys in the scheduler to optionally add required traits to ensure that the instance can land on a host that's capable of the requested behavior;
- The libvirt driver will then interpret the values separately to decide whether to use the features during live migration.

For example, if the flavor says "false":
- We don't add the trait to the scheduling request, so the instance can land anywhere; but
- The driver will *not* use the feature for live-migrate, regardless of what the compute's config says.

as implemented by libvirt/qemu post_copy can be considered a specialisation of auto_converge.

as with auto_converge there is an initial pre_copy phase that initially  copies the guest memory/exectuion state and then if migration does not complete before a specific treshold post_copy is initieated.  my understanding is the delta between auto_converge and post_copy is that when auto_congerve would normal slow the exectuion of the guest on the souce to allow the pre-copy to complete when post copy is enebaled we instad transtiaon to the post copy phases and switch exectuion to the dest host instead of slowing the execution on the source.

This is currently set to false because we saw cases of live-migration failures due to the forced raw image conversion taking too long. 

I'll let Chris/Gerry chime in on this but this could be a problem.

I don't think we want to do this unconditionally, as we have seen problems in the past with live migration.

As I recall, the issue showed up when live migrating instances that used local storage with boot-from-image and qcow2 images that expanded to *large* raw files on spinning disks such that the conversion took quite a while.

I think the most robust thing to do would be to only set force_raw_images for nodes that have rbd storage enabled.  This would require specifying it from the per-node portion of the sysinv overrides rather than in the manifest.
Pretty sure this commit could go in before 640271, and I think it would actually be a valid change to make to save users from misconfiguring the system.

I have not seen the patch[0] in stx.2. If stx.2 includes it, we should need the change.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/640271/

So do you mean that if I set force_raw_images to true here, it will apply to all the nova.conf after we deploy the nova service?
If so, how can I do that inly for nodes that have rbd storage enabled? :( Sorry, I am a new for the starlingx/config project.

Yes, setting force_raw_images to true here would affect all nodes.  It would make more sense to conditionally make this change in _get_per_host_overrides() or the functions that it calls in "https://github.com/openstack/stx-config/blob/master/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/nova.py" depending on whether or not rbd storage is enabled for each host.

Sysinv has the ability to set per-node overrides, and has the knowledge of whether or not each host is using rbd storage, so it's the natural place to make this change.

This isn't really accurate, or it could be confused as thinking multiple cells share the same MQ, which they don't, that's the point. Cells is mainly a way to shard and scale a nova deployment while maintaining a single API endpoint (as the description said before) so you don't have to do something like regions. So maybe just say, "Shard and scale compute deployment while maintaining a single :term:`API endpoint`."
Done

I guess you'd be referring to nova-conductor here and optionally nova-metadata (depending on how that is configured), but that's not really overhead IMO, that's kind of the point in horizontally scaling the services rather than having a single nova-conductor (or a cluster of nova-conductors) managing all nodes. Or maybe you mean multiple MQ/DB instances. Anyway, this is probably fine to leave what you have.

Yeah I'm not sure if Overhead is supposed to mean like "downsides to deploying with this option" or if it just means "things you have to do above and beyond a normal deployment", I think it's probably the latter and if so what you have here is fine.

I don't really get the point what **Overhead** means here. From my understanding you have an overhead of installed services to increase the availability. To compare with other columns there are changes in nova.conf (???)

This is true for cells v1 and I think we can fudge to say it's logically true enough for cells v2, but it's not really technically, cells v2 is flat but there is a top layer where there are no computes but it's not really called an "API cell" and those controller services at the "top" are generally tracked in the cell0 DB.

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/cellsv2-layout.html#multiple-cells

Anyway, you don't have to re-word this, but maybe you could find a way to work in a link to https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/cellsv2-layout.html? Even something as simple as, "See <link: Cells Layout> for topology details."
I would either remove this or re-write it to say "The ``nova-compute`` service runs in the child cells."
Done

This makes it sound like there is a shared MQ and DB which there isn't, so I would keep what was here before and just say, "Each cell has its own message queue
and database service."
Done

This term is a bit off, when I think of "cloud installation" I think of a full openstack deployment, including cinder/neutron/glance. Maybe it would be better to just say "compute" rather than "cloud" here? The main thing that runs in the multiple child cells is the nova-compute service and each child cell has its own MQ and DB. Beyond that we assume external services like neutron and glance are global to the cells, or are at least affined using something like availability zones across services. Anyway, that's probably more detail than you want here, I'd just re-word "cloud installations" to "compute installations".
Done

I don't know much about non-IP protocols, but I'm fine with making this all-or-nothing for an ethertype, we shouldn't be in the business of seeing what is supported in the firewalls wrt flow matching some additional bit of info.

I agree; the fact that there is likely no commonality to the conventions of various ethertypes any more than there is between those ethertypes and IP means any attempt to impose IP semantics on them will end in madness.  FCoE, for example, uses Fiber Channel addressing within an Ethernet frame (IIUC).  IPoIB is different; that has layer 2 = IP but layer 1 is InfiniBand, not Ethernet.

swift/common/middleware/slo.py.message: wondering if it would be possible to get a 404, but not from a tombstone, maybe just from fetching from handoffs that never heard of this obj?? in this case we shouldn't return a 503 correct? thoughts?
Absolutely possible, but it wouldn't have a timestamp. As a result, the response is considered "old", leading us to the 503.

> in this case we shouldn't return a 503 correct?

Oh, I misread the comment as we *should* return a 503! Sorry.

No, I very much think that 503 is appropriate. We know there's newer data (it had an X-Static-Large-Object header which sent us down this path), but when we tried to get all of it, that request failed. It wasn't available when we knew that it should be.

Now, the client will most likely handle that 503 by retrying the request, and that will be reasonably likely to 404 all on its own. But *at that point* we don't have any reason to second-guess that -- we've lost all the context that made us think the object should exist.
k, this is the case for getting the same SLO object as the initial request but now got a non-2xx response.

test/unit/common/middleware/test_slo.py.message: it is possible to get a 404 without a tombstone?

For sure; see above comment. There are two flavors of 404, and they only differ in this one header. If there's a tombstone on disk, you'll see something like

 < HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
 < Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
 < X-Backend-Timestamp: 1563584905.59010
 < Content-Length: 70
 < Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2019 15:32:33 GMT

If there isn't, it's more like

 < HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found
 < Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
 < Content-Length: 70
 < Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2019 15:32:42 GMT

specs/rpc-health-checks.rst.message:
We already have this built into all services in the form of the ping() method. It's used by compute to halt startup until at least one conductor service is running, since compute requires conductor for basic operation:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/conductor/api.py#L66

You should be able to ping() any service that is running and listening for RPC calls.

That said, nova also already kinda does this in the form of service checkins. Meaning, if RPC is working, compute writes its liveness to the DB via conductor. The other services do the same, but directly to do the DB.

To me, health checks should really be done as described previously, via supporting the normal http-based health checks on each service, which can then report things like whether or not RPC seems to be working, among other things. Doing it in-band with RPC doesn't really tell us much that the existing service reporting isn't already telling us. If the rpc in-band check works, then likely the service checkin is working as well.

Further, the above-mentioned probe tool puts a non-nova component on the private nova rpc bus, which isn't a very good idea, IMHO.

> @Dan Firstly, apologies for not managing to grab you at the PTG for
 > a quick hallway discussion on this.  Had too many other things to
 > think about :-/
 > 
 > > That said, nova also already kinda does this in the form of
 > service checkins. Meaning, if RPC is working, compute writes its
 > liveness to the DB via conductor. The other services do the same,
 > but directly to do the DB.
 > 
 > This is of course useful, but to me it doesn't feel like a complete
 > solution to the problem of pin-pointing failures during automated
 > root cause analysis or self-healing.  For example, if a service's
 > liveness updates cease to appear in the DB, that doesn't give us an
 > accurate read on where the failure is.  For example, it could be an
 > issue with the DB or the network on the DB end, or with the network
 > on the service's end, or an issue with the whole machine running
 > the service.  All of these are of course significantly different
 > failure modes to "there's a problem with the service".

Sure, which is why I'm saying a direct-to-the-node health check that doesn't rely on any of the other services is likely to give you a lot more detail. For example, if you're unable to contact it over RPC, that could be because (a) rabbit is down or (b) conductor is down and the threadpool on the compute has become exhausted trying to check in.

 > To clarify, are you suggesting that RPC-only services which don't
 > currently expose an HTTP endpoint should do so?  That's something
 > the community has been considering for quite a while in the context
 > of the health check APIs discussion:
 > 
 > https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2001439

Right.

 > but it has been a somewhat controversial suggestion, with some
 > people concerned about potential bloat and impact on the
 > security/deployment model.  Having said that, Dirk and I did
 > discuss it with Ben Nemec on Saturday just as the PTG finished, and
 > he didn't seem to have violent objections. (FWIW personally I
 > haven't made up my mind either way yet.)

I think it's a lot more useful than relying on RPC, which is the most likely reason for an unhealthy service (IMHO and IME).

 > If OTOH you are suggesting that the existing HTTP endpoints should
 > act as proxies for RPC component health, then I'm pretty sure
 > that's not going to work for the reasons stated above.

No, I'm talking about individual shared-with-nothing endpoints. Super simple, minimal bloat, based on something generic that other projects are using for similar things.

 > "likely" is the key word here.  As mentioned above, for effective
 > RCA via the likes of Vitrage, and effective managment by the likes
 > of k8s, we need checks to be as accurate as possible, otherwise we
 > can't build self-healing workflows which we can trust to do the
 > right thing.  For example, if the conductor dies, we can't afford
 > our compute liveness probes to trigger false alarms, even
 > momentarily.

In any real deployment you have many conductors across multiple nodes (even in the smallest of arrangements), so all of them falling over at once is not very "likely". Further, if you're going for RCA, and you find that no conductors are up (or even that some are down) then the dependency graph tells you that worrying about computes being up is pointless. Meaning, just from nova's service reporting, I can tell a lot:

 1. Are any conductors reporting? If no, then rabbit or conductor. If yes,
 2. Are any computes reporting? If no, then rabbit, if yes,
 3. Only some computes are reporting, likely problem with the non-reporting computes (or their networks)

 > This is an interesting point.  Any chance you could elaborate on
 > your concerns here?  Of course an RPC liveness probe would have to
 > act responsibly and not spam the bus, but are there other risks
 > here, e.g. security-related ones?

A polling approach to liveness checks over the RPC bus is going to add load to the single most loaded service in openstack, rabbit. Any additional load you add there is going to go unappreciated by large deployments. My biggest concerns, however, is that on our bus, we are in charge of all the schemas, interfaces, and upgrade compatibility. If you introduce an interface for a health check, that's something nova exposes which it does not consume, and opens us up to the situation where our bus is not intended to be private. It means the external services now have some expectation of stability of that interface, which we manage internally for everything at the moment.

In general, Nova has external APIs at the REST layer and the metadata service and that's it. We take extreme care to keep those stable. Our RPC interfaces are private, versioned, and lifecycle managed internally. Altering that would be a pretty big change, and not for a really significant gain, because as I said, I think an http api per node would be a *lot* more useful, as it can continue to report information independent of pretty much everything else.

Got it, thanks. Along with the discussion in IRC just now[1] I think you've persuaded me that this is the right way to go.  New dedicated endpoints specifically targeted at exposing this health data seem to have several advantages over doing it over RPC.

So maybe we should abandon this spec and consolidate efforts with https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2001439

The third option which was discussed at the PTG but not mentioned on this review until now, was the Guru Meditation Reports offered by oslo.reports.  However these reports are dumped to STDERR by default, so that behaviour would need some tweaks before it would be easily consumable by a container liveness probe or similar.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-05-07.log.html#t2019-05-07T17:50:38

@Dan Firstly, apologies for not managing to grab you at the PTG for a quick hallway discussion on this.  Had too many other things to think about :-/

 > That said, nova also already kinda does this in the form of service checkins. Meaning, if RPC is working, compute writes its liveness to the DB via conductor. The other services do the same, but directly to do the DB.

This is of course useful, but to me it doesn't feel like a complete solution to the problem of pin-pointing failures during automated root cause analysis or self-healing.  For example, if a service's liveness updates cease to appear in the DB, that doesn't give us an accurate read on where the failure is.  For example, it could be an issue with the DB or the network on the DB end, or with the network on the service's end, or an issue with the whole machine running the service.  All of these are of course significantly different failure modes to "there's a problem with the service".

Additionally, if another service such as conductor is proxying the liveness, then that adds another layer of failure modes which can potentially muddy the waters.

 > To me, health checks should really be done as described previously, via supporting the normal http-based health checks on each service, which can then report things like whether or not RPC seems to be working, among other things.

To clarify, are you suggesting that RPC-only services which don't currently expose an HTTP endpoint should do so?  That's something the community has been considering for quite a while in the context of the health check APIs discussion:

   https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2001439

but it has been a somewhat controversial suggestion, with some people concerned about potential bloat and impact on the security/deployment model.  Having said that, Dirk and I did discuss it with Ben Nemec on Saturday just as the PTG finished, and he didn't seem to have violent objections. (FWIW personally I haven't made up my mind either way yet.)

If OTOH you are suggesting that the existing HTTP endpoints should act as proxies for RPC component health, then I'm pretty sure that's not going to work for the reasons stated above.

And even though we *do* potentially want to expand the existing HTTP endpoints to provide not just health-check data but also internal performance metrics (which was the main thrust of the Saturday discussion), this is out of scope for the specific use case we are trying to address here, i.e. allowing accurate liveness probes from k8s to RPC services.  In that use case, k8s doesn't need anything more than a simple binary dead-or-alive answer.

 > Doing it in-band with RPC doesn't really tell us much that the existing service reporting isn't already telling us. If the rpc in-band check works, then likely the service checkin is working as well.

"likely" is the key word here.  As mentioned above, for effective RCA via the likes of Vitrage, and effective managment by the likes of k8s, we need checks to be as accurate as possible, otherwise we can't build self-healing workflows which we can trust to do the right thing.  For example, if the conductor dies, we can't afford our compute liveness probes to trigger false alarms, even momentarily.

 > Further, the above-mentioned probe tool puts a non-nova component on the private nova rpc bus, which isn't a very good idea, IMHO.

This is an interesting point.  Any chance you could elaborate on your concerns here?  Of course an RPC liveness probe would have to act responsibly and not spam the bus, but are there other risks here, e.g. security-related ones?

Very nice input!
I guess the next question for that topic is whether or not a common approach should be taken, and how other projects are doing. I suppose the next step would then be to contact other projects to see if they have implemented the same approach, and have a view of what needs achieving over the whole community to establish a common approach.

specs/train/per-physnet-interface-driver.message: How could this happen? You mean we will run multiple l2 agents (for instance linux-agent and ovs-agent) in one single host, then L3 and DHCP can use any of these drivers?

For the L2 wiring, yes.

The interface driver creates the OS entity (e.g ovs internal port, veth pairs, ipoib interfaces as in the first use case below), L2 agent acts on the creation of this entity and performs the needed L2 wiring.

It is possible today to run several L2 agents on the same host (to deal with the binding of ports of different types or on different physnets)

The goal of this spec is to allow an L3/DHCP agents to use different interface drivers (per physnet). The wiring of the created interfaces will be handled by different L2 agents.
This can be a baremetal Cloud, Hypervisors running VMs or a mix of boths.

Do we support to run both openvswitch and linuxbridge agents on same host in same time?
I don't think that this is good example really.
Technically it is possible but I'm really not sure if this is valid use case :)

Technically it is possible (i didnt find a limitation in the code, is there?)

Neutron is able to support several ML2 drivers and their agents can co-exist in the host.

I agree it's less likely someone will do it.
IMO instead of providing new driver we can modify code which currently is using drivers that it would use different driver for ports connected to different physnet.

Another alternative is to regard the `multi` interface as an "interface driver manager" (it will not subclass LinuxInterfaceDriver). Objects like namespaces, routers will use it instead of directly invoking an interface driver.

Its kind of a semantic alternative.

Its in the alternatives section, however taking this approach will require extensive changes in all objects using the interface driver, some of them are not aware of the notion of a network like namespace objects.

Thanks for the information.
So, after the exception, the agent side will have stale resources remained?
Unbound port has empty host in port context, so no agent is returned by host.

Version: Queens, size of deployment: 80 nodes, non-DVR. gtw node hosting over 1000 ports, during constant resources creation/deletion can see described errors in neutron server logs.

Happens not in l2 pop mech driver update_port_up but in ml2 rpc update_devide_down: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/rpc.py#L258
I don't have an exact repro procedure, I just saw this error on a production environment, got the traceback and saw that port context may return empty host.

According to the change you mentioned here:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/640797/19/neutron/plugins/ml2/rpc.py Left Line 331.
The original code did not cover a None agent for a regular port as well.

This is the original code without the commit a5244d6d44d2b66de27dc77efa7830fa657260be :
"""
        if (port['device_owner'] == n_const.DEVICE_OWNER_DVR_INTERFACE and
                not l2pop_driver.obj.agent_restarted(port_context)):
            return
"""

So, a port_context with None host will still be sent to the exception place for a reguler port. That is saying the commit a5244d6d44d2b66de27dc77efa7830fa657260be is not related. So here 'back' and this reference commit in this commit message should be replaced with a precisely statement.

So in original code quoted above if port has device_owner != DEVICE_OWNER_DVR_INTERFACE - agent_restarted() will not even be called. Commit a5244d6d44d2b66de27dc77efa7830fa657260be changed that behavior, so that agent_restarted() called always, no matter which device_owner a port has.

keystone/api/os_ep_filter.py.message: The filter should be passed to the enforcer, for example like here https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/src/branch/master/keystone/api/services.py#L37-L38

Using a kwarg here isn't really necessary since the method signature of the callee doesn't define hints as a kwarg. We could just:

  PROVIDERS.catalog_api.list_endpoint_groups(hints)

Or we could adjust the method signature to actually make hints a real kwarg and provide a reasonable default of None (which is something we do elsewhere).

  def list_endpoint_groups(self, hints=None):

Keeping the call and the signature of the callee in sync helps readability regardless of which piece of code you're reading.

deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-dashboard.y.message:
I'm not sure these lines need to stay here or it's better to handle this section in ceph-base.yaml.

Basically from ceph-ansible point of view we have many roles that need to be executed to deploy the dashboard; each role, of course, has its own parameters, so here we have two sets of variables:
1. "dashboard_enabled: true", needed in group_vars/all.yml; it triggers the execution of the dashboard deployment playbooks (in site-container.yaml.sample), so it's a global variable we need to set when the " -e /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/environments/ceph-ansible/ceph-dashboard.yaml" is added;

2. grafana, prometheus+alertmanager, dashboard (mgr role): we have 3 roles involved here and we need to set these variables according to the playbook role they belong to

We know all.yml will exist because on line 94 we include the resource to create it so it should be safe. It would be safer if we had a way to get it into the map before we wrote it to the file though. Perhaps add it as a new property on line 103 and default it to false in your update to ceph-base.yaml but then hard code the pass of true to it on line 103 in this file. It's worth a shot. 

It's on the border of nit picky, but seems a little safer.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/const.message: I don't think this should be pulled from the /opt/backups directory. The existing restore code was restoring the file to /etc/sysinv and using it from there. Why did you change this?

Tried again by restoring crushmap backup file in /etc/sysinv. During ctlr0 unlock some content in /etc/sysinv were regenerated but crushmapbackup file was intact. So it looks like I had bug somewhere in my early version of restore code. 

Regarding whether to store the ceph crushmap backup file in /etc/sysinv or /opt/backups, after discuss with Bart offline, this is what we will do:

The existing restore code was putting the crushmap backup file in /opt/platform/sysinv. When it's time to create ceph osds  this file was moved to  /etc/sysinv and renamed as crushmap.bin. (If it is not during restore, crushmap.bin is generated by compiling one of the ceph model files (crushmap.xxx.txt) in /etc/sysinv.). In the new restore code, because /opt/platform/sysinv is not available when applying ceph manifest at ctlr-0 unlock time we will store the crushmap backup file in /opt/backups. And then when it's time to create ceph osds,  move it to  /etc/sysinv and rename it as crushmap.bin just like what the existing ceph restore code did.

I will try again to see what really happens.

And I feel that /opt/backups may be a better place to store the backup version of the crushmap. When we restore the crushmap we will copy it over to /etc/sysinv and remove it from /opt/backups.

Also I store the mariadb data in /opt/backups/maridb before restore them during restore_openstack phase.

The existing restore code was restoring the file to /opt/platform/sysinv/${software_version/. I couldn't retore the file there because during restore for AIO-SX, the crushmap is set in puppet (ceph.pp) when unlocking controller-0. But at that time /opt/platform/sysinv/${software_version} is not mounted yet. 

Then I tried to restore the file to /etc/sysinv. But that didn't work either because when unlocking controller-0, /etc/sysinv is re-created and so the restored file is gone.
What code is deleting the contents of /etc/sysinv on the unlock? That doesn't seem right.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ce.message: This file will only be visible on controller-0. Is restore_ceph_config only invoked on controller-0?

This commit is only for restoring an AIO-SX. There will be more commits to restore other configurations.

Some background info:
- restore_ceph_config is not invoked when restoring AIO-SX or AIO-DX.

- Because for AIO-SX and AIO-DX the ceph crushmap is set in puppet code when unlocking controller-0 when /opt/platform/sysinv which is a drbd fs is not available yet, I have to store the backup crushmap somewhere else - I chose /opt/backups. Yes, during AIO-SX and AIO-DX restore, ceph crushmap is only set on controller-0

- For Standard non-storage configuration, ceph crushmap is set on controller-0 via sysinv during unlocking controller-1 when the 2nd ceph mon is up. I can store the backup crushmap to /opt/platform/sysinv although it is not a must.

- For storage configuration, ceph crushmap is set via sysinv after the 2nd storage node comes up. If during restore before unlocking the 2nd storage node, controller swact happens, we need to make sure the backup crushmap is also available on controller-1. So yes, for storage configuration, we need to store the crushmap in /opt/platform/sysinv.

So I think you are saying this code change isn't necessary for now and that it is going to have to be different in the final implementation anyways. I'd prefer you just add a good TODO comment here rather than making a code change that isn't sufficient anyways.

My other comment is that I don't like this code (which is going to be invoked regularly on a running system) looking in the /opt/backups directory, which we really don't have control over. I would prefer that you use /opt/platform/sysinv in the non-AIO cases if you can and in the AIO cases, give the file a special name and put it under /etc/sysinv.

OK. I will use /opt/platform/sysinv for non-AIO cases and /etc/sysinv for AIO cases. The backup crushmap is named crushmap.bin.backup which is different from the normally generated crushmap which is crushmap.bin. So I think we don't need a special name for the backup crushmap for AIO cases.

nova/api/openstack/compute/services.py.message:
Unrelated to *this* change but related to the issue cdent pointed out in the commit message ( and recreated in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663737/ ), counting the instance uuids on the host is akin to the cascade=True logic in delete_resource_provider in that it's only checking for instances that are currently on the host because of the instances.host value in the database. But it's not counting other allocations on the resource providers like unconfirmed migrations and evacuated instances. Given that, to fix the ResourceProviderInUse issue we have a couple of options, which I don't think are mutually exclusive:

1. we could change this check to look for allocations on any resource providers on the host
2. we could change delete_resource_provider to not ignore ResourceProviderInUse so that if we fail we don't delete the compute service record until the allocations on those providers are cleaned up
3. we change the cascade=True logic in delete_resource_provider to cleanup all allocations on the provider, not just for the currently hosted instances

The one thing that worries me a bit about #3 is if we're cleaning up allocations for unconfirmed migrations, what happens when the migration is confirmed/reverted and the compute service code goes to remove/change the source node allocations that we've now deleted? I'm not even sure if we'd get that far if the source compute service is deleted while an instance is in VERIFY_RESIZE status and then the user confirms/reverts the migration.

The easiest / most straight-forward thing we can do now is probably #2 while mulling #3 (and write a functional test or two for the #3 scenario).

Okay, so refreshable application credentials would not be needed *at all* if autoprovisioning is used? Meaning federated users, who are persisted to keystone as shadow users, would always be able to use their application credentials even when they are removed from the IdP backend?

This will be a good spot for an *example* explanation of how a consumer of this file format *might* be implemented. (Emphasis to reinforce the fact that we're not speccing such an implementation here.)

The example of pre-cyborg/nova-only device passthrough would go something like this:

The virt driver, which is by definition platform/hypervisor-specific, is responsible for:

- Discovering devices on the system
- Constructing resource providers corresponding to those devices

The author of the providers.yaml file is responsible for knowing what platform/hypervisor it's going to be deployed on, reading the docs that describe how to use the file on that platform/hypervisor, and thereby understanding which of the addressing mechanisms she should use and how it's formatted.

For example, the doc for libvirt might say:

 ============

Run lspci -D. The first field is the PCI address in d:b:s.f format. To allow passthrough of a particular device, e.g. one with address "0000:0d:00.3", add a stanza in your providers.yaml file that looks like:

 ...
 providers:
     - identification:
         pci_address: 0000:0d:00.3
       ownership:
         service: nova
       passthrough:
         allow: true
 ...

 ============

The virt driver, in update_provider_tree, having discovered devices on the system, and knowing their PCI addresses, parses the providers.yaml file, gathers a list of `pci_address` values from stanzas with `ownership.service==nova` and `passthrough.allow==true`, filters the list of discovered devices accordingly, and creates resource providers for whatever's left.

Whatever spec actually designs the above process should also prescribe what those resource providers should look like: the convention for naming them, where they will be in the tree hierarchy, what traits will be automatically generated on them by default, what their inventories will look like by default (based on device type), etc. And the salient subset of that information will *also* be included in the same doc so that the author of providers.yaml will know how to construct the remainder of their stanza if they want to e.g. switch off one of those automatic traits:

 ...
     customization:
         traits:
             remove:
                 # This trait is normally generated by libvirt, but we don't
                 # want it in this case because blah blah blah.
                 - CUSTOM_FOO
 ...
the operator also can use this YAML file to do the same thing, then we can keep this YAML file as a generic resource provider tree editor, keep it isn't related to any specific type device.

This file doesn't dictate a mechanism for *removing* a provider from placement. It only provides a way to say `passthrough.allow=false`. What this sentence is saying is that it'll be up to the consuming implementation to decide how that actually manifests in placement, which may or may not comprise removing the provider.

But maybe you're saying we should turn this into a generic mechanism, not device-specific, for dictating that a provider should be unavailable (possibly absent, possibly without inventory, possibly with reserved==total, whatever).

I did consider that, but thought it would be best left for a future version of the file, if and when we decide we need it. The reasoning is:

- We don't have a use case for blacklisting providers *other* than devices.
- We want providers *other* than devices to show up by default; but (for compatibility with the behavior of [pci]passthrough_whitelist as well as the VGPU work in progress) we want devices to *not* show up by default; they must be explicitly whitelisted.

Thus, devices are getting special treatment anyway. I tried to come up with some generic way to say "this provider should be visible or not" while at the same time making it understandable that "devices are not visible by default, but everything else is". I felt as though this way made the latter most explicit without compromising the former, since we don't need "not visible" for anything other than devices.

This stimulates a question that was lurking throughout this: Who/what is reading this file. In my head I've been thinking it has to be in all the places where something is going to be writing to the placement api because it is operating as what amounts to a filter between what it thinks it wants to write and what it is allowed/supposed to write.

Which makes it all start to seem a bit weird as much of the point of having things like the resource tracker talk to the placement API was so that this kind of thing could be automated. If we're making it "normal" to have to filter those things then we've gone a bit astray.

So: this needs to be an edge (pun intended?) case.

Which is not to dispute the need for the file and format, I agree we do, but I think we need to document that it is special/rare.
I added a sentence under `Proposed change` analogizing this with oslo.config.

Exactly this. (The way the compute service is set up, the composition is done by the virt driver, while the actual "writing to the placement api" is done by the resource tracker, but it amounts to the same thing.)

Well, yeah, automated as much as possible. I say on L396 that services should strive to behave sanely if the file is absent.

 > If we're
 > making it "normal" to have to filter those things then we've gone a
 > bit astray.

Not sure I agree with this statement. I'm not saying we should go crazy supporting every possible permutation of this file for every possible provider. It's really no different than having oslo.config available to us, whereby we can define config options that feed into how things get manifested in placement. We are cautious about adding new config options: we do it when we see a need for it.

I guess the difference is in how directly this file maps to the placement database. That proximity could give one the impression that we're going to implement some kind of generic placement editor engine that consumes this file and just lets the file's author rewrite placement willy nilly. That is pretty darn unlikely to happen... but I don't feel like it's the place of this spec to dictate that we shouldn't do that.

 > So: this needs to be an edge (pun intended?) case.

Yeah, I struggled with this and went back and forth on it. What it comes down to is this: some providers/resources should be exposed by default (e.g. compute nodes, eventually their treed components such as NUMA nodes or storage fabrics...); whereas things like devices should be forbidden by default, needing to be explicitly enabled for passthrough.  It sucks, but we're probably going to have to document that dichotomy somehow. So for example, your file might need one paragraph allowing passthrough of a device, and another that makes a particular storage provider not show up on this node.

The other case to consider in the future is if I want to say, "expose all devices of this type, *except* for this one". Then instead of having N-1 "allow" clauses in the file, I could have two: one saying "allow all of this type" and the other saying "don't expose this one device".

Not sure this is exactly what you meant to say. Perhaps you meant to say "An admin wishes to indicate that the host NUMA cells should be taken into account for workloads scheduled to that host".

Alternately, you might be confusing CPU pinning with NUMA? Maybe you meant to say something to the effect of "The admin wishes to indicate which host logical processors should be used for dedicated guest CPU resources and which should be used for shared guest CPU resources"?

Yeah, "define" is a poor word. Perhaps s/define a/describe the system's/. For example, whenever we figure out how we're going to do it, perhaps this file is used to set the traits that associate affinitized providers with each other.

So yes, pinning use cases, but the long-term goal (at least to my understanding) is to be able to say, "make sure resources A,B,C for this VM have the same NUMA affinity," without having to say, "get the resources for A,B,C from NUMA node X."

Open to suggestions for a better way to word this sentence, BUT I definitely don't want to try to solve the NUMA problem here. Willing to exchange vagueness for terseness.

specs/train/approved/provider-config-fil.message:
1. Security aspects of this file. Who owns it?
2. How can we prevent duplicates in creation of resource providers? Sanity check of the file.
3. Sanity check against exiting parent uuid/ uuids for aggregate rps entered in the file.

Presumably we support only one version of the file at any given point and this is just our sentinel to refuse to load it if it's not what we expect, right? And the rules for said versioning are? Additive only, otherwise bump the version?

Technically we're required to support config files from N-1 in version N as part of our upgrade promise. Meaning, we can't require operators to roll code and config changes simultaneously. So, I think it's important that we describe what the situation around revving the version/format would be.

For the first pass, we should limit the ownership and consumption of the file to nova only. So it must be readable by the nova process and writable by the same users/groups as nova.conf itself.

I think 2 and 3 are addressed below somewhere, but: Yes, validate, and refuse to start the compute service if we find errors/conflicts/discrepancies.

IMO at least a major.minor makes sense. Additive bumps minor; compat breaking bumps major. That way a consumer can distinguish between "can I handle this at all" and "new feature X available".

I suppose that can be done with a monotonic integer as well, but it seems more awkward.
Do we support overrides to standard resource classes or traits, and does the file take the final precedence?

With the caveat that only certain kinds of overrides are supported, yes, they're allowed, and the file takes precedence. Examples:

It could be one way to remove DISK_GB inventory from the root provider and create it in a sharing provider, to feed shared disk functionality [1].

> 1. Support flavor to extend to numa_llc? Can you clarify how NUMA based CPUs and memory is modeled in placement today?

It isn't. That's been my whole point from the start. VCPU and MEMORY_MB are all lumped together on the root provider.

> $ openstack flavor set m1.large --property hw:numa_nodes=2
> $ openstack flavor set m1.large \  # configure guest node 0
>   --property hw:numa_cpus.0=0,1 \
>   --property hw:numa_mem.0=2048
> $ openstack flavor set m1.large \  # configure guest node 1
>   --property hw:numa_cpus.1=2,3,4,5 \
>   --property hw:numa_mem.1=4096

This results in a call to placement for VCPU:6,MEMORY_MB:6144. Then the NUMATopologyFilter tries to satisfy the split to real NUMA nodes. If it can't do that, it fails, resulting in a reschedule. Three such failures in a row, we bounce the whole request.

This is why it is important for us to *start* modeling NUMA nodes in placement. The placement features to support this, including [1] as of yesterday, are now available. But significant work needs to be done on the nova side, and making that a dependency of this spec is likely to delay it beyond Train.

> 2. If we create child rps for LLC, they should still be associated with cores that can use them.

And as things stand today, you can't guarantee that. You have to choose between two poor alternatives:

(A) Model your LLC all together in the root provider. That way you get to pick which cacheways to assign to the VM, so you have the possibility of satisfying affinity -- BUT there's no guarantee the allocation you've been given will be able to be satisfied completely from the correct NUMA node(s).

(B) Model your LLC in child providers split along NUMA lines. Then you're guaranteed each allocation will all come from a single NUMA node. But placement plus the NUMATopologyFilter is only going to guarantee that your VCPU and MEMORY_MB are affined appropriately to each other. It *is* still possible that, once those filters have passed and the instance has started to spawn, your VCPU/MEMORY_MB will be allocated from one NUMA node and your LLC from another. And there's absolutely nothing you can do about it. You can't even late-fail the spawn.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/placement-api-microversion-history.html#support-same-subtree-queryparam-on-get-allocation-candidates

@Eric, we might have reviewed this question before, but would like to try my luck for some clarity.

The LLC usecase in RMD - We can expect an LLC per NUMA - which means 

1. the scheduler can account for cache ways from each the NUMA bound LLC. 

Considering that all the LLC have the same size, one workaround is to report it as max=<size of single LLC>, total=<sum of sizes of all LLC>). 

For e.g. on 2 node NUMA system, if size of LLC=10, we can report as max=10, total=20. So user can request upto 10 so that we can apply it against one of the LLCs.

2. The user must co-locate cores and LLC to same NUMA or request LLC allocation from all NUMA nodes (for floating CPUs).

To keep things simple, we can expect user to start with requesting dedicated CPU cores, but there is no way to guarantee that CPU cores will belong to same NUMA as LLC.

For e.g. max=10, total=20
LLC0 - 1 cache way free
LLC1- 3 cache way free

a request for 2 cache ways, for cores 0,2,4 might select this node, since total LLC available=4, but we actually do not have 2 cache ways to give from LLC0.

It is hard to move root provider inventories to NUMA based child provider inventories, but until then we can expect incorrect scheduling. Please let me know your thoughts.

I sympathize with the problem here. I'm trying to find every possible way to reduce the scope of this work for the current release.

The max_unit trick is clever, but a) it still won't prevent you from getting allocations that can only be satisfied by spanning multiple NUMA nodes; and b) it easily breaks when more than one isolated guest NUMA node is requested. (The max_unit is enforced for the whole allocation, not per request group.)

We're going to have to deal with reshaping regardless of whether the resources start off on the compute node RP or nested RPs, so that aspect is moot.

Rejecting a scheduling request because we can't allocate the requested amount of LLC from a single NUMA node is an improvement (though far from a complete solution since it's still possible to allocate from the *wrong* NUMA node(s)). So it's really just a question of whether that improvement is worth the added complexity of supporting creation of new providers at this time.

If we decide the answer is yes, the use case should be phrased in terms of the ability to group/split resources to reflect how they exist on the host, *not* in terms of topology/affinity, because we absolutely have no way to affect that yet.

The example may focus on the exposure of the core frequency boundaries rather than the "capable/non-capable". On a power efficient CPU all the cores will be able to enable or disable the P-State kernel handling. The exposure in placement is interesting when used in combination with SST-BF as you can describe the cores in terms of high/low tier under their respective NUMA node.
In this particular case, once the resource are described in placement, it should be possible to get core resources from multiple NUMA nodes under a single VM.

> > The example may focus on the exposure of the core frequency
 > > boundaries rather than the "capable/non-capable". On a power
 > > efficient CPU all the cores will be able to enable or disable the
 > > P-State kernel handling.
 > 
 > Right, but I thought you couldn't enable or disable on the fly. So
 > you have to preconfigure which are enabled and tell nova which CPU
 > IDs are which by piggybacking on the PCPU/VCPU split.

That step is for SST-BF to split the cores into high and low and then "enumerate" them using the PCPU/VCPU implementation. 
The P-States control can be done even without enabling SST-BF. All the cores will have the same maximum[1] frequency and you can set them not to fluctuate, to be fixed on the min or on the maximum frequency. That provides a more deterministic behavior.

[1]In this case "maximum" is lower than the "maximum" you'll get on a group of cores when using SST-BF.

 > However (I'll say this more than once in this review) anything out
 > of band that's RMD or BF or P-State related WILL NOT be able to
 > late-fail the spawn. You have to take what you get from the
 > NUMATopologyFilter.

Yep, we have changed the RMD flow design to not expect late failures as agreed in the PTG. We are looking for other options to verify policy compatibility before spawning the VM.

> The example may focus on the exposure of the core frequency
 > boundaries rather than the "capable/non-capable". On a power
 > efficient CPU all the cores will be able to enable or disable the
 > P-State kernel handling.

Right, but I thought you couldn't enable or disable on the fly. So you have to preconfigure which are enabled and tell nova which CPU IDs are which by piggybacking on the PCPU/VCPU split.

 > The exposure in placement is interesting
 > when used in combination with SST-BF as you can describe the cores
 > in terms of high/low tier under their respective NUMA node.

Noting that "under their respective NUMA node" is still hypothetical at this time.

 > In this particular case, once the resource are described in
 > placement, it should be possible to get core resources from
 > multiple NUMA nodes under a single VM.

Yes, that's possible today even though all the resources are in the same provider, because the NUMATopologyFilter processes the hw:*.$N extra_specs to ensure resources from NUMA node $N -- and late-fails if it can't find enough from NUMA node $N.

However (I'll say this more than once in this review) anything out of band that's RMD or BF or P-State related WILL NOT be able to late-fail the spawn. You have to take what you get from the NUMATopologyFilter.

Don't you mean $Major, 0..N ? Presumably you want any minor version changes to be backwards and forwards compatible. Meaning, I can put extra stuff in the config file which corresponds to a newer version of the schema, but since it's all additive, it won't break older code not yet ready to see it.

If that were the case, we wouldn't need $minor at all (which I think is a point you've made before).

The idea is for optional additions to bump $minor; and anything else to bump $Major.

So let's say I'm at 1.2 and then I add an optional identification.name. I bump to 1.3 because a 1.2 schema won't validate any document with an identification.name in it (because additionalProperties: false), but 1.3 will still validate any 1.2 document.

But if I make identification.name required, now I have to bump to 2.0, because *all* 1.x documents will fail validation under 2.0, because all 1.x documents are missing the identification.name field.

I think you're missing my point. The compute host is the thing that runs the compute *service*. That service and machine are not the thing(s) that provide the resource, and that's why the uuid of the *node* is what goes into placement. If we call this $COMPUTE_NODE, then (a) you're using the right terminology and (b) it becomes natural to apply anything under that point to any compute node managed by the compute service, including ironic nodes. No fancy templating needed, just apply that to any node.

Right, so this goes into implementation detail a bit, but we've talked about doing it like this:

- Generic compute service does file loading and schema validation, resulting in a JSON blob.
- We provide a ComputeDriver._update_provider_tree_from_parsed_providers_yaml_blob() implementation, because as you say, understanding how to edit the provider tree based on the strictly-defined generalized schema defined here is something we should only need to write once.
- The virt driver's update_provider_tree is responsible for calling self._update_provider_tree_from_parsed_providers_yaml_blob(), if it wants to support providers.yaml, at whatever point in update_provider_tree makes the most sense for it.
- We would not expect (though I suppose not forbid) virt drivers to override the method. Rather, we would expect them to pre-/post-process the json blob if necessary before/after calling the method.

We decided to punt on this by only allowing CUSTOM_ traits. So, since it's also additive-only, there can't be a conflict (if you add a CUSTOM_ trait that was already present from upt, no harm no foul; and upt doesn't get to declare "ownership" over traits that are CUSTOM_ so it can't get mad if you add one it thinks shouldn't be there).

Based on the flow suggested at [1], merging the file into the provider tree would happen from within update_provider_tree, and the RT does automatic trait work *after* that [2]. So traits managed by nova [3] are applied (added or removed) afterward, which means they'll indeed take precedence.

(I'm not sure that's the right thing, actually, based on my arguments elsewhere for why we might eventually need to be able to *remove* automatic traits. But assuming it is...)

> How does an individual ... know which traits are managed by nova

They pretty much don't. But this is an existing problem, manifested if you use e.g. osc to add/remove a trait and then some time later nova-compute periodic removes/adds it back for you. This is explained to some extent at [4] and [5].

However, the manifestation here would be a little cleaner because you wouldn't have to wait some indeterminate amount of time for periodic to override - it would happen before the changes are even flushed to placement.

So I guess the answer is: "You can tell because the trait in your file will never show up on the provider (and since there's no way we have a bug in our code, this is obviously by design)."

Need to rework this section. We agreed that the flow will be as follows:

0) On startup, the resource tracker loads files from the directory specified by CONF.compute.provider_config and schema-validates them. Schema validation failure blows up the compute service. On successful load/validation, the resulting dict blob is saved as an instance attribute on the resource tracker.

Then, during the resource tracker's _update_to_placement flow (so on periodics etc.):
1) driver.update_provider_tree is invoked, as today [1]. It doesn't know about provider config, has no ability to pre-/post-process it. (If we decide we want that at some point in the future, we can pass the config into upt. But not now.)
2) Automatic traits processing happens, as today [2].
3) Provider config is now merged with the provider tree. Inventory conflicts (meaning reference to existing resource classes) log a warning. If `startup` is True, also blow up the compute service. (It should be very difficult to generate a conflict on not-startup; this is for extra safety.) If `startup` is False, ignore the conflicting piece of the inventory.
4) update_from_provider_tree (flush to Placement), as today [3].

NB: We will only support provider config in the update_provider_tree code path. It will not be processed in the get_inventory [4] or compute_node_to_inventory_dict [5] code paths.

[4] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1036-L1039
[5] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1041-L1045
